comments.commentBody: New York has changed in my lifetime.  I worked at Danceteria and lived at Grand and Lafyette in the mid 80's before the old Centre Street Police station was turned into pricy apartments and gangland dropoff's for bodies were anywhere they wanted in my neighborhood.  It was a grim time in the summer when I lived downtown.  You couldn't turn off the lights in the unairconditioned loft.  The cockroaches would stream out of the drains both the kitchen sink and the bathroom drain.  The Vietnamese lobster shop on the first floor was not clean, their refrigerated truck would belch black stuff into the loft all night long.. it was not pretty.... New York is a parody of the 80's and certainly a parody of the 70's the 60's and every decade prior.. it is in flux constantly.  Like in Blade Runner.  Soon only replicants will remain.

I had a college professor at Yale who specialized in Victorian literature. He always said he wished he had lived in that period. Right. No antibiotics, consumption (sic., tuberculosis ) ran rampant, infant mortality at 50%, need I go on?

The "good old days" were, and still are, a fantasy. But I guess if you're a drunk sitting in the Subway Inn, it's reality.
There is something comforting about a place where you don't have to worry about damaging the decor.

I'd only been a few times, but instantly loved it. I felt like I was transported to a space where status slipped away and anything was possible, surrounded by the various souls who could find their place in that marvelous, decrepit room.

Wow. I hope she drew herself up in her very best posture, looked him(?) straight in the eye and said something like "Based on where I'm from, I can offer you hard work, loyalty, kindness, and ethics. Based on where your firm is located, I wonder if those values even count with you?" and got up and walked out, haha!
See also Girlhood (Bande de filles), a film by Céline Sciamma http://www.tiff.net/festivals/thefestival/programmes/next-wave/girlhood-1
The righties might argue that growth could be worse, but they have a hard time explaining away their record deficits, which they predicted would be lower as a result of tax cuts.

One summer in the late '70s or early '80s I worked at Bloomingdales and drank occasionally at the Subway Inn.  I was living at the time near Columbia on the Upper West Side and frequented Cannon's Bar at 108th St. and Broadway, another dubious drinking spot that is also no more (it has been replaced by a similar but slightly better kept establishment with a different name).  Imagine my surprise when I discovered that I was not the only patron whose leisure hours pursuits straddled these two taverns that stood almost three miles apart: There was also a woman known to regulars at both as "Anne the Artist", who produced commissioned portraits on cardboard for a modest fee.  Alas, her one-of-a-kind rendering of Muhammad Ali has not survived my many relocations since I paid her $5 for it.

Pride is important in the Appalachian Mountains. Earning your own way is important too. You may not have much, but what you do have you have because of your blood, sweat, and tears -- not because of housing assistance or food stamps or TCA. Your trailer may be run down, but that's because you bought it with cash you earned working at the tannery. There are programs and politicians willing to "help" those who live below the poverty line in Appalachia, but applying for them is a compromise and accepting them is admitting defeat. Not to say that voting Republican is the answer -- not with today's options -- but that party was once based on the bootstrap philosophy that's so deeply ingrained in a majority of those who were raised and live in the Appalachian mountains, and change takes time.

Thank you. I was hoping someone would point out that sexual assault can be just as traumatic  even if there's  not penetration  involved. There is no such thing as a little bit raped. That's  like saying that a woman who has suffered psychological  abuse from a spouse has been less abused because she wasn't slapped and kicked.

During college I worked at nearby Serendipity.  After the late shift, exhausted, we would fall into the Subway for drinks.  It was like entering a black hole.  The grimness and despair was so overwhelming your two drinks felt like ten.  It was perfect.
Did you actually read the books? This scene was horrific in the novel. Of course the healing was just as emotional but the scene with BJR and the reflections told a horrific tale.

Governors (like Presidents) are not dictators who get to implement the policies they want, UNLESS state legislatures agree.

Nixon is a Democrat, but Missouri's state legislature is controlled by the GOP.
Brownback is a Republican, and Kansas' state legislature is controlled by the GOP...who implemented everything he wanted!

And you, like all of Brownback's defenders, keep avoiding the basic point: Brownback promised if the state legislature gave him traditional trickle-down Reaganomics, complete with massive tax cuts for the rich and corporations, massive spending cuts to education and public services, that Kansas would produce fantastic job growth, fantastic wage increases, fantastic state revenue, GDP growth, etc.
What did Kansas get? Massive skyrocketing debt (the projected deficits have been doubling roughly every six months, despite Brownback's assurances of a soon-to-be-balanced budget), slower than average job growth, slower than average GDP growth, slower everything (except wealth growth by the top earners and corporations). Whether or not he's doing better than one particular state or not is meaningless. He has FAILED to keep his promised result!
Your daughter sounds amazing!

I am the mother of a 8-year-old girl who has CP. For my daughter, CP is not the most debilitating medical issue she deals with (she has chronic lung disease which causes respiratory distress), but it is the one that most people notice.

The thing is, she is not the child I dreamt of, the one I thought I wanted. The one who would be a dancer, a skier, a gymnast. The one who would wear cute dresses with tights and maryjane shoes. The one who would love science and be great at math.

Instead, she is who she is. A girl who cries when faced with a dress, who loves to play soccer on her adaptive team, who wants me to sign her up for baseball, one who is scared to ride a bike or go up steps unassisted.

Perhaps the trouble is children usually defy expectations; children with special needs just make that clear much earlier.
most of these girls were 14 or 15 when they became pregnant, or shall we say, raped.
Just keep reading... or in this case watching! Diana covers all the bases. Just be patient!

The finale was riveting. Jaimie and  Clare's devotion and love for each other enables them to get past the most untenable situations. That being said, Claire will never return to 1945. Her future is in the past. She was never baron, Frank was probably sterile, and I cannot wait for the next season. I am addicted to these characters and the story. Fantastic actors make the whole concept very believ able and fascinating!!
Amen Sista!!
Claire was never actually raped by the British deserter. She killed him before he could start the act.

Claire IS the hero of this story. She's much stronger and more able to deal with adversity than any of the men. Claire has gone through a World War that would have surpassed anything the Highlanders could even imagine, and done it as a nurse, facing physical and emotional horrors beyond the Scot's experience/comprehension. So....even if she had been actually raped during her assaults, I think she'd have handled it better than any man of that period would, with their limited scope of what masculinity is.
So Karma is a 500 pound Highland cow? I'd like to see that happen. :)

Anyone else notice that Black Jack's right hand got mangled by the stampeding cattle early in this episode?  I bet the next season has him with worse/more permanent hand injuries than Jamie, owing to Claire's 20th century skills.  I have not read the books, so I'm just guessing here.

I've read the first book, can't get through the second, and I bought the series but not sure I'll get through reading them all. But the show has been compelling, thoughtful, rich, and complex. Honestly graphic but not gratuitously so, it covers depths of emotional pain and recovery for a victim of torture such as I've never seen in a television series. The acting is superb and I can only imagine how difficult these scenes were to film. I loved the romantic sweep of the earlier shows and now I am willing to pay the price - realizing that just as every human being has a gritty backstory, so should every well done fictional character.

I believe the things that happened to Jamie were described in enough detail by him in the book to bring about these scenes in the show.  Everything that happened in the episode was something Jamie described to Claire in the book.  The rape (although they left out the whipping in the show), the constant back and forth from Randall of inflicting pain and then tenderness, Randall wanting Jamie to profess love to him, Randall's jealousy/annoyance with Jamie's love of Claire (the hold she has on him), etc.  They actually left out alot of the bloody moments, and the moment when Randall becomes crazed.  I felt what was displayed was enough to show the audience how horrific the prison time was but not as excessive as what was laid out in the book.  I do agree with you that it would have been nice to have more time devoted to Claire trying to reach Jamie in the darkness, rehabilitate him, heal him.  Even an additional 10 minutes added to the show would have been helpful and not left me feeling that the episode was too long.

I didn't think about that regarding the monastery.  In the book, the monastery is in France and Jamie's uncle is the Abbot.  Ron Moore said they altered the location to Scotland to keep the tension of them still being hunted by the Redcoats present.  In the book, that tension appears in the day or two when they are at MacRannoch's after Jamie's rescue, and needing to treat him so he will be ok to travel to France.  Perhaps they decided it was a small concession for the consolidation of the story for the tv adaptation.
Claire was not raped.
